When I first started as a beg I forced myself to draw 2 hours a day every day to forge the habit for about a month (1 hour would probably work too).
Then I felt the form for the first time and all of a sudden I actually wanted to draw because it was fun. Hours I spent drawing naturally began to increase.
So yeah, building the habit to start with is the most important thing. Give yourself the time to find out if you actually enjoy this hobby. Check in with yourself every couple of months to see if you’re happy bumping your hours up a bit, but no matter what keep that hour as a baseline. Unless you’re 100% sure you hate drawing. Then quit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: There's a lot to practice to "get good" at art in general. An hour is great, but really doesn't give you too much wiggle room in one session. Ideally during each drawing session you'd try to do some book studies/copies, some observational drawing from life or photos, some copies of other artworks, and some drawing from imagination (where you'd try to gradually incorporate what you picked up from the other exercises). In just an hour you'll probably have to focus on one, maybe two, things. At first I'd say focus on your raw observational work, since improving that will help speed up and increase the efficiency and effectiveness of your studies. You don't have to be a photocopy master, unless that's your personal art goal, but at least reach a point where you can copy well enough to learn things as well as meaningfully make use of references in your work.

>i asked her to sketch a front and profile view of a teacher in 5 minutes.
kek. you must be a programmer to think that way about how long it would take to make something worthwhile from scratch, on the spot, with new specs, and nothing going wrong and no misunderstandings. that's the amount of time it might take to mechanically make the sketch, but not enough if you include reading and understanding the brief, and thinking about a concept. I've worked with too many software devs who estimate how long things will take in that same way.

given enough time, the idea of asking for a sketch like whiteboarding a small coding problem isn't inherently bad, though. when comics were more popular in the 50's, I think it was a common component of an interview -- but in that context, it was for entry level artists who were hired to knock out derivative shit quickly without screwing around. I don't think you will find someone at the level you're interviewing at who can pass that test very well, unless you get very lucky. that's almost kim jung gi-tier shit unless your in-house style is all balls and hoses.

that drawing does suck, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
i just did this and wanted to add something that occurred to me that hadn’t been said yet:
if you’re hiring someone through hourly wages, it might actually be a bit of a bad thing for the interviewees if they explode their brains in dashing out their 110% best in that five minutes, and you get a really good result, because this opens up whole frontiers of potential uneasiness for the artists in working with you since they know you already do things irregularly (interview content:) it might seem like you could dually be irregular in the output demands you make of them, and in the payment (without weird questions,)
because employers with irregular processes feel like they could be unreliable, so it might feel to them that you might say way down the line when they’d already invested a lot in you:
‘why are you charging me for this great amount of time for ok things when you showed me you did that great design back in the interview in five minutes? you’re slacking and lying about the time it took, I’m disappointed in you (or, i’m not going to pay all that, there’s no way it could’ve taken you hours.)
creative energy is exhausting, and the adrenaline rush and superman focus in that five minutes could never be maintained consistently through the whole work day, so even if they did their best, it might feel like they’re shooting themselves in the foot, because they’re unsure of you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't fuss about it like some people do. drawing people, figures, anime 3d models and such is a better way of learning the form of something than by studying anatomy. That's important because, when stuff looks off, they usually say "go study anatomy", and so you waste a few hours looking at some bicep anatomy or whatever without actually getting any better forms. What you should really do is draw figures and 3d models and stuff, and like y'know, do some actual drawings. Anatomy doesn't teach form very well, it's more just to help when you're confused / having trouble with some particular part and want to know it better, so you take a peek inside or want a higher level of detail (which if you like cute things, you don't want). It isn't the main meat and potatoes, but a dish on the side; you genuinely shouldn't using it 90% of the time.

The reason why it's bad for form is kind of obvious when you think about it, your brain is not a 3D modeling program that can by know what something looks like from assembling internal ingredients. You're better off just looking at what it looks like, and putting it in ur visual library by drawing it. This is how artists naturally draw - from the visual library. they know what it's supposed to look like, and then try make it look like that, except pretty and good.

It's not good to be confused or lack understanding, but it is good to wing it as an artist, for most things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6503833
you just need to know how the muscles are placed and how they flow and interconnect with each other. Understanding how the bones affect the appearance on the outside is helpful too, say in areas like where the humerus connects with the tricep and creates that distinct shape and form. Metacarpals in the hand, cheek bones and planes of the face and the way they look from the outside under the flesh. It's good to have some general idea of what's going on under the skin to know what you're looking at on the outside.

The most important thing I'd say, is to make sure to look at photos of the outside of the body while you're studying bones and muscles, because sometimes it's difficult to connect what you're looking at under the skin to how it should look from the outside.

Didn't made me question why I draw, personally- I just do, I always did and always will.
It did actually challenge my outlook on art a little. Is art just a pretty picture? Then why do this machine vomit doesn't move me in the slightest? I'm not even disgusted at it or intrigued by some of the horrors it spit like some DeviantArt abominations did.

There's nothing there.

Reinforced this idea I entertained, that art is a form of communication. A natural rock can look beautiful, but I wouldn't call it art, it has nothing to say. Same deal with machine-made pictures. It doesn't say anything, it only manages to parody what was already the lowest, most derivative forms of art. I think this is what people mean when they say "Soulless", something that earnestly attempts to convey an idea, even without proper skills to back it up, is infinitely more powerful and resounding than anything a machine can make.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6496876
The jump from trad to digital has its challenges if you go to screenless. But going screen tablet the hurdle is much less. You can get some cheap XP-Pen 16, 13 or 12 screen tablets. I bought the Innovator 16 in 2020 and now they came up with the 2nd Gen 16" tablet which is about half the price of my Innovator 16. (The only downside is the lack of dials). The other hurdles are picking the right color and right shading (if you're worried about messing up your coloring, just eyedrop until you the hang of it).

What you definitely should do is explore your drawing app for shortcuts, key modifiers and templates/auto actions as it could half the amount of time you'd spend working. Eg: I bind the alt button to common tool eraser so I dont need to switch tools to erase at all. It cuts down 1-2 seconds, but it adds up. Ctrl+Shift is for layer select, so I could immediately jump to which layer I want to work on by tapping on the screen instead of layer hunting in the layer window/tool panel.

Consider this: as a /beg/, you're going to need tons of mileage. Hundreds of hours of drawing. If you go digital only, you're going to have a set time out of your day where you need to be at your computer doing nothing but drawing. Can you resist the urge to open up a web browser, fap, play vidya, etc.? Do you have a block of your time you can be at your PC? Just something to consider. Otherwise, no, it doesn't really matter, I'm sure there are plenty of successful cartoonists who are primarily digital only.

>>6496876
Starting with digital art as a beginner is not necessarily wrong, but it's important to understand that the skills developed in digital art are not exactly the same as those developed in traditional art. The skills you hone in digital art are centered around the use of software and technology, while traditional art focuses more on fundamental techniques.

However, starting with digital art can be tempting, especially if you're interested in doing cartoon or stylized work, as you can quickly achieve results with the tools available in digital art software.

A potential pitfall of starting digitally is that it can be tempting to rely too heavily on the tools and shortcuts provided by the software, rather than developing your fundamental drawing skills. This can result in a lack of control over the creation process and a lack of understanding of traditional techniques and mediums.

If you do decide to start with digital art, my advice would be to start by learning the traditional techniques and principles of drawing, such as anatomy, perspective, and lighting. This will give you a solid foundation to build upon as you learn the digital tools.

Additionally, consider trying out traditional mediums, such as pencils and charcoal, to help you understand and develop the core skills involved in creating art. This will also give you a more well-rounded skillset and make it easier for you to transition to traditional art down the road, if you so choose.

posts.com:
While not anime uniquely, I think the focus on stylization is an important trend.

Historically it was all about capturing reality as realistically as possible, but with cameras and other modern techniques its extremely easy to do that.
For awhile that forced artists to delve into the abstract and other nonsensical forms of expression, but lets be honest, its just a laughable subversion that only got popular because everything thought they were being clever by calling a toilet art.

The focus on stylization such as that seen in anime allows for expression of purpose and ideas. Instead of limiting yourself to drawing things as realistic as possible, you focus primarily on the ideas and concepts you want to show off, and because you don't need to be tied down to the static nature of realistic figures or the inflexible proportions they have, it lets people be more creative with what they're expressing.

Something like pic rel would be completely impossible to replicate by the old masters because real women are ugly and have right feet.

>>6494920
I agree, but less pessimistic about AI being the end of drawing and art. I do think AI will accelerate style trends, generic brands of anime and digital art ('artstation' style) will oversaturate and burn out.
I think we'll return to highly individualistic artist styles. If you look at early American comic strips there was a diversity of styles, from surrealist funny animals to realistic cinematic strips.
The influence of anime/manga is huge. Its effects will be more subtle though (for instance, though I draw in an American style, I'm inspired by the pacing of manga). I think we'll see more international style(s), with artists absorbing all these global influences to develop their quirky styles, with also a return to traditional media to differentiate from the AI behemoth.
Of course, no one has a crystal ball, but history shows that with art every action has a reaction. Artists tend to be very resilient to adapting to changing technology and society, but often in unexpected ways.

>>6490877
It's true that anime has gained popularity and has its own unique style, but to say that it's the "new Renaissance" is an overstatement. The Renaissance was a cultural, historical, and artistic movement that greatly impacted the Western world and set the foundation for modern art. It was a time of great innovation and experimentation in the arts, which had a profound influence on the cultural, political, and social aspects of society.

Anime, on the other hand, is primarily meant to be lighthearted entertainment. It is enjoyed by many for its unique storytelling, colorful characters, and imaginative worlds. While it can contain elements of art, it is not meant to be taken as a serious artistic movement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6507713
Normals care about how art is made when the product is marketed as "artistically worthy," whether directly or implied.

Think of any A24 film. People look at those films more critically than others because the product insists to be examined by the way it is filmed, by the creative decisions made, by the marketing material, etc. Scale this down to an indie artist and you have the same thing. For example, If your "brand" is to make porn of popular characters, then no one gives a single fuck how it's made because the end result is what people want to jerk off to, not the process. Another example; if you style your work as being made be someone who is young, then that implies to the audience that the art is more impressive because it was made by someone young, even if it's not that great. Replace 'young' with 'woman' or 'disabled' and you have the same effect. You can also market the process more than the actual art, showing off speedpaints or sketches along with the art. The more content you give people to examine, the more people examine it, its really that simple. For example, some of the marketing material for A24 films prominently features director interviews, behind the scenes stuff and so on.

Normies are easy to manipulate. You feed them information, then they spit that information back out but also say "I'm smart for making these connections," when in reality they are making a connection between 2 and 1+1. if you want people to care about your art process, make the process more prominent in your "marketing" and also in the stylistic choices you make in your art, like making it more painterly or making the limitations of the program you are using be more noticeable. Artists are not impressed by these things though, they're either doing the same thing as you or see right through those cheap tricks as you trying too hard to be artsy. Artists are harder to impress their dog whistle for noticing how something is made is genuine skill and subtlety.

>>6507074
Yeah, I don't get making full fan worlds and the like, especially when with a few tweaks you can make it your own thing (see: 50 Shades of Grey). In terms of random drawings? They can more easily grab attention, it can be fun to play with somebody else's concepts, it's good practice to learn different styles and character designs, and it allows you to try techniques within a set of design parameters without having to design characters from scratch. Beyond that, it depends on your goals. If you're wanting to work in the mainstream animation or comic industry, there's a good chance that a lot of what you do for work will effectively be fanart.

All eventualities, the base alloy needs the strength to hold the diamonds. This is a design; for a necklace; that uses white gold, consisting of gold, platinum and silver. Perhaps, these three elements could be melted together easily and used for jewelry? Indeed, not. It is a complicated process, of yet, unnamed and little known, however results can be achieved which fully satisfy the jeweler's need. Mind you, some benefit from this comes in the form of a higher heat hardening effect. The wire is drawn and wrapped in these 3 shapes: *drawing1 The rings are arranged into a chain. Two larger round ones, followed by one oval and one smaller. *drawing2 Tin, and only tin, is used in place of solder. It is called, eutectic bonding. The touching surfaces of the jump rings are dipped with molten tin. And into the oven at high temperatures for long hours. Gold and tin are eutectic, melting at lower temperatures, allowing diffusion, thus closing the rings. The necklace envisioned in this design, should be kept as small as possible. To each his own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6505696
I strongly believe if you can't see the value of Oda's art you're ngmi. At the very least pre-timeskip Oda's art, before the clutter got worse and worse.
>sense of scale
The world in One Piece is detailed and big. This should be reason enough since 60% of manga in general don't have backgrounds. Usually if other mangakas ever pull back the camera to show the background it's relegated to assistants slapping filters over a photo of Tokyo. Oda's environments fit in with the characters, they stretch and squeeze, but they are always drawn in the same style as the characters so it feels like Oda draw them personally.
>range
Oda's just wiling to draw so much, and so many different kinds of things. There is no comfort zone for this guy, every arc is a different aesthetic. Even in OP's pic alone you see so much texture, of the wood, metal, clothes, the scales of a dragon. It's not rendered like your ruan jias but in a way it takes a lot of imagination to let the materiality of physical objects come through in black and white. (early one piece especially has almost zero screentone too)
>no comfort zone
As an artist he has genuinely no fear of "what if I can't draw this?" which makes a lot of artists stay in a rut, ie. not drawing the second eye, close-ups and no perspective, drawing the same subjects over and over again.
>is never tired
take all of the above and realise he does this shit on a weekly schedule.

Lacks line confidence. You have generally got things going in the right direction but you need to not make composite ("hairy") lines.
>>6489478
>>6489618
For coloring, you need to learn your tools a bit better. That as a completed image should only take you 3-4 hours of work at the absolute most. Things like using masks, auto-color tools, how to paint bucket effectively, and so on immensely helps with that kind of cel shading you're doing.
Try disabling Ctrl+Z for a month.


Basically your problem is that you are taking too long to complete each stage of a drawing. Accept your imperfections with the knowledge that producing art faster makes you better.
Making 5, increasingly-detailed sketches overlaid on top of each other using confident strokes takes less time than the 2-3 you did there using unconfident strokes.

Additionally your commission sheet needs to have its basics easily grasped from a twitter/deviantart/etc thumbnail. Offered levels of polish and prices primarily. Never use "percentages" to change pricing, and discounts look better than additional fees.

Let’s be honest, Bob Ross never painted anything that merited description beyond “trees in front of a mountain with water in the foreground”.
His paintings are (arguably by necessity of their intended purpose) extremely formulaic, low effort and devoid of thought, sentiment or value and painted entirely with “this quick easy trick makes artists mad click here to find out more” type nonsense like putting light and dark values on either side of the brush and just daubing to get random rocks with inconsistent lighting instead of teaching you to paint a fucking rock. Not once does he even reflect on the actual craft, he uses painting as therapeutic technique that utterly devalues the effort.
He’s like Kinkade if Kinkade had to make his paintings replicable by actual retards in 20 minutes.
Setting aside his therapeutic endeavours, altruism and nostalgia, he never contributed anything whatsoever to art, and that narrow context might as well have been painting prolapsed Chun Li assholes all day.

posts.sub: How to start painting as an illustrator
posts.com:
As stated in the title, I have been drawing for quite a while, almost exclusively with pencils and pens (and sometimes colored pencils) on both traditional and the digital format. My issue is that I really want to expand my horizons with painting and getting practice and better at it, but my issue is that I have no idea where to start.

I've been so used to having lines to block in and define my pieces that I do not know how to approach painting, which relies on shapes and colors instead of lines.

I just want to ask anyone here on how I should approach the subject and what techniques I should use to be able to paint better without just looking like blobs?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6507104
painting is just learning to use your medium, nothing else is different except technique. start with monotone to get handling of paints then start doing glazing and shit, go on youtube for videos or google some intro courses

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6507119
I understand that but what my issue is trying to understand how to visualize how I’m going to paint.

Because with pencils and pens, I envision the lines and where each line goes for things such as shape, shading, depth, etc. Painting, on the other hand, is exclusively about colors and one needs to visualize where and what colors to use to do the aforementioned form, shading, depth, etc.

How do painters do that?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6507104
it will take years to learn to draw. it takes a few hours to learn to paint. decide what medium you want and look up some videos. ryan o'rourke does very longform acrylic tutorials you can follow along with and learn blending and color mixing technique. explains how to color match and so on. painting is entirely about matching colors and how to mix paint. like 90% is mixing paint and how much water on the brush, etc.

acrylic - relatively cheap, easy to clean and deal with water. youll be surprised how much water is needed to do stuff though. can dry up fast if not careful, so not always best starting medium, but cheap enough that you can afford to 'waste' some paint learning.

gouache - cheap like acrylic, but more a mix of acrylic and water color with how much water is used in. can even do wet on wet like water color for underpaintings. can reactivate paint with water very easily. pro and con since harder to do layers sicne you can fuck up the thing you are painting on top of if not careful as beginner. very easy to to use though. recommend starting here personally. simple stuff like ghibli landscapes look great and you could just print out/trace/grid transfer line art over and paint by number almost to learn with. lots of videos of people doing it and himi jelly set is cheap and lot of colors that can make mixing a little easier and color matching simple.

water color - i hate this shit. so fucking messy and easy to fuck up as a beginner. was frustrating as a lot of it is 'drop some color into already wet area and let it spread randomly'. didnt feel like i was in control even if it looked good. your milage may vary. i just hate how much water gets everywhere and constant drying shit up and if want to mess around its still expensive paper (relatively speaking) since cheap shit buckles. your milage may vary.

anon's gateway into painting, by me, anon

start with acrylics, it's the most standard way to go by. start with monochromatic palettes.
get your:
- 1 titanium white tube
- 1 ultramatine blue tube
- 1 raw umber
don't even get your own blacks, mix it by using: 1 part ultramarine blue, 1 part raw umber. the cooler or warmer you want to get, slightly add more of ultramarine blue or raw umber respectively.
- round and tall brushes, get the cheapest shit you can find in a bundle like pic related
- a palette. some ppl use window frames (lmao my oil painting professor) from the dumpsters or cheap mirrors. i use paper plates with aluminum foil wrapped around them (paper absorbs the pigments)
- canvases, buy the back stapled canvases, the flat panel ones have texture on them that's an eyesore if you don't plan on laying paint thicker
- sacrifice a cup to the arcylic lords, for water
- heavy duty/industrial soap, like orange or lava soap (has grains in it that removes a lot of gunk from your hands, even oil)

invest in a blowdryer to paint within layers faster, especially for the sake of practice. then if you want more vivid work, you can get into oils. but don't until you're actually ready for oils, because they're expensive as hell and the whole practice of safety is a turn off for many (hence why acrylics are more popular).

when you get more comfortable, buy your cool and warm primary paint

if you meant painting digital then well, shit lol
digital is an entirely different ballpark.
w/e, have fun anon

They trained the model to support what they wanted to find:
"Our attack extracts images from Stable Diffusion most often when they have been duplicated at least k = 100 times; although this should be taken as an upper bound because our methodology explicitly searches for memorization of duplicated images.

In order to evaluate the effectiveness of our attack, we select the 350,000 most-duplicated examples from the training dataset and generate 500 candidate images for each of these prompts (totaling 175 million generated images). We first sort all of these generated images by ordering them by the mean distance between images in the clique to identify generations that we predict are likely to be memorized training data."

any brush with extremly soft edges or fuzzy pattern + opacity can blend by simply applying multiple strokes over same place. Works the best with black color, a bit worse with other colors.

airbrush does the same thing, but instead of multiple brush strokes you simply hold it over the darker places longer.

there are also dedicated blending tools who take two colors from the areas and then produce midtone with some blending in the middle.
